sentence-detokenized: FOOTBALL - JAPAN WINS LUCKY, CHINA IN SURPRISE DEFEAT.
Japan began the defence of their Asian Cup title with a 2-1 win against Syria in a Group C championship match on Friday.
But China saw their luck desert them in their second group match, falling to a surprise 2-0 defeat to newcomers Uzbekistan.

China controlled most of the match and saw several chances missed until the 78th minute, when Uzbek striker Igor Shkvyrin took advantage of a misdirected defensive header to flick the ball over the advancing Chinese goalkeeper and into an empty net.
Oleg Shatskiku secured the win in injury time, hitting an unstoppable left-footed shot from outside the area.
The former Soviet republic were playing for the first time in an Asian Cup final tie.
Despite winning the Asian Games title two years ago, Uzbekistan is in the final as an outsider.
Two goals from defensive errors in the last six minutes allowed Japan to come from behind and get all three points from their opening meeting against Syria.

Takuya Takagi scored the winning goal in the 88th minute, rising to head a cross from Hiroshige Yanagimoto towards the Syrian goal that goalkeeper Salem Bitar appeared to have covered but then allowed to slip into the net.
It was Syria's second costly error in four minutes.
Defender Hassan Abbas rose to intercept a long ball in the area in the 84th minute but could only divert it into the top corner of Bitar's goal.
Nader Jokhadar had given Syria the lead with a well-taken header in the seventh minute.
Japan then besieged Syria's penalty area for most of the game, but rarely breached the Syrian defence.
The fine guitar pull saves every time they do it.
Japanese coach Shu Kamo said: '' The Syrian goal itself proved lucky for us.
The Syrians scored early and then played defensively and adopted long balls, which made life difficult for us. '
Japan, co-hosts of the World Cup in 2002 and ranked 20th in the world by FIFA, are favourites to regain their title here.
Hosts UAE play Kuwait and South Korea face Indonesia on Saturday in Group A matches.
All four teams are level on one point each from one game.
RUGBY UNION - CUTTITTA BACK TO ITALY AFTER A YEAR.
on Friday for their friendly against Scotland at Murrayfield, more than a year after the 30-year-old wing announced he was retiring after international differences.
Cuttitta, who manager George Coste said was certain to play on Saturday week, was named in a 21-man squad missing just two from the team beaten 54-21 by England at Twickenham last month.
Stefano Bordon is out through illness and Coste said he had left Corrado Covi, who had been called up for the England game after five years out of the national team.
Cuttitta announced his retirement after the 1995 World Cup, where he objected to being dropped from the Italy team that faced England in the group stage.
Coste said he had approached the player two months ago about a return.
"He finished the World Cup on the wrong note," Coste said.
"I thought it would be useful to have him back and he said he would be available."
I think now is the right time for him to come back. "

Squad: Javier Pertile, Paolo Vaccari, Marcello Cuttitta, Ivan Francescato, Leandro Manteri, Diego Dominguez, Francesco Mazzariol, Alessandro Troncon, Orazio Arancio, Andrea Sgorlon, Massimo Giovanelli, Carlo Checchinato, Walter Cristofoletto, Franco Properzi Curti, Carlo Orlandi, Massimo Cuttitta, Giambatista Croci, Gianluca Guidi, Nicola Mazzucato, Alessandro Moscardi, Andrea Castellani.
FOOTBALL - LATE GOALS GIVE JAPAN VICTORY OVER SYRIA.
Two goals in the last six minutes gave defending champions Japan an uninspiring 2-1 win over Syria on Friday.
Takuya Takagi headed the winner in the 88th minute of the group C game after goalkeeper Salem Bitar spoiled an errorless display by allowing the ball to slip under his body.
It was the second Syrian defensive error in four minutes.
Defender Hassan Abbas rose to intercept a long ball in the area in the 84th minute but could only divert it into the top corner of Bitar's goal.
Syria had taken the lead in its first serious attack in the seventh minute.
Nader Jokhadar headed a cross from the right by Ammar Awad into the top right corner of Kenichi Shimokawa's goal.
Japan then besieged the Syria area and had a goal disallowed for offside in the 16th minute.
A minute later, Bitar produced a good double save, first from Kazuyoshi Miura's header and then blocking a follow-up shot from Takagi.
Bitar saved well again from Miura in the 37th minute, keeping out his header from a corner.
Japan started the second half brightly but Bitar denied them an equaliser when he dived to his right to save Naoki Soma's low drive in the 53rd minute.

FOOTBALL - BAN ON RAISED FLASHING LIGHTS.
Dutch striker Reggie Blinker had his indefinite suspension lifted by FIFA on Friday and was set to make his Sheffield Wednesday return against Liverpool on Saturday.
Blinker has missed his club's last two games after FIFA banned him worldwide for appearing to sign contracts for both Wednesday and Udinese while playing for Feyenoord.
The FIFA players' status committee, meeting in Barcelona, decided that although Udinese's document was basically valid, it could not be legally protected.
The committee said the Italian club had breached regulations by failing to inform Feyenoord, with whom the player was under contract.
Blinker was fined 75,000 Swiss francs ($57,600) for failing to inform the Engllsh club of his previous commitment to Udinese.
FOOTBALL - LEEDS 'BOWYER FINED FOR PART OF FAST-FOOD BRAWL.
Leeds' England under-21 striker Lee Bowyer was fined 4,500 pounds ($7,400) on Friday for throwing chairs at restaurant staff during a disturbance at McDonald's fast-food restaurant.
Bowyer, 19, who was caught in the act by security cameras, pleaded guilty to a charge of affray in a London court.
He was fined and ordered to pay a total of £175 to two staff injured in the fight at an east London restaurant in October.
Leeds had already fined Bowyer £4,000 ($6,600) and warned him that a repeat of his criminal behaviour could cost him his place on the sidelines.
Bowyer, who moved to the Yorkshire club in August for 3.5 million pounds ($5.8 million), was due to play against Middlesbrough on Saturday.

RUGBY UNION - LITTLE TO MISS CAMP BYE.
Centre Jason Little will miss Australia's end-of-day match against the Barbarians at Twickenham on Saturday.
Little opted not to risk aggravating the knee injury that ruled him out of a large chunk of the tour and was replaced by fellow Queenslander Daniel Herbert.
Owen Finegan has recovered from the knocks he suffered in last weekend's Test against Wales and retains his place in the back row ahead of Daniel Manu.

The Wallabies are aiming for a 13th consecutive win to finish their European tour with a 100 per cent record, but they also want to turn on the style and offer David Campese a proper send-off in their final match in Australian colours.

The Wallabies currently have no plans to make any special appearances for the 34-year-old singer, but a full house of 75,000 spectators will still gather in the hope of witnessing one last moment of magic.
Campese will face a familiar foe in the form of captain Rob Andrew, the man who kicked Australia to defeat with a last-gasp goal in the World Cup quarter-final in Cape Town.
"Campo has a huge following in this country and has had the crowd with him since he first played here in 1984," said Andrew, also likely to be making his last appearance at Twickenham.
On tour, Australia won all four Tests against Italy, Scotland, Ireland and Wales, and scored 414 points at an average of nearly 35 points per game.

League duties have restricted the Barbarians' selective options, but they still boast 13 internationals, including England full-back Tim Stimpson and Tony Underwood, plus All Black forwards Ian Jones and Norm Hewitt.

FOOTBALL - PLAYERS WITHOUT HELMETS CALLED UP TO FACE MACEDONIA.
Romanian coach Anghel Iordanescu called up three uncapped players on Friday in his squad to face Macedonia next week in a World Cup qualifier.

Midfielder Valentin Stefan and striker Viorel Ion of Otelul Galati and defender Liviu Ciobotariu of Nacional Bucharest are the newcomers for the European group eight clash in Macedonia on December 14.
Iordanescu said he had chosen them because of their good performances in the national championship, in which Bucharest National are leaders and Otelul Galati third. "
I think it's fair to give them a chance," he told reporters.
League title holders Steaua Bucharest, who finished bottom of their Champions League group in the European Cup, have just two players in their squad.
Attacking midfielder Adrian Ilie, who recently moved to Turkish club Galatasaray from Steaua, is ruled out after two yellow card offences.
Defenders - Dan Petrescu, Daniel Prodan, Anton Dobos, Cornel Papura, Liviu Ciobotariu, Tibor Selymess, Iulian Filipescu.

CRICKET - LARA ENDURES ANOTHER MISERABLE DAY.
Australia gave Brian Lara another reason to be miserable when they beat West Indies by five wickets in the opening match of the World Series by limited overs on Friday.
Lara, disciplined for misconduct on Wednesday, was sacked for five years to extend a disappointing run of touring.
Australia, who hold a 2-0 lead in the five-match Test series, overhauled West Indies' total of 172 with eight balls to spare to end a run of six successive one-day defeats.
Rounder Greg Blewett led his side to a comfortable victory with 57 off 90 balls to the delight of the crowd of 42,442.
Man of the match Blewett came to the wicket with a total of 70 for two and hit three fours during an uneventful innings that lasted 129 minutes.
His crucial fifth-wicket partnership with fellow pacer Stuart Law, who scored 21, added 71 off 85 balls.
Lara looked out of touch during her brief stay at the crease before chipping a simple catch to Shane Warne at mid-wicket.
West Indies tourism manager Clive Lloyd apologised for Lara's behaviour on Tuesday.
He (Lara) had told Australian coach Geoff Marsh that wicketkeeper Ian Healy was not welcome in the visitors' dressing room.
The Melbourne crowd were clearly incensed by the incident, loudly jeering at the West Indies vice-captain as he walked into the middle.
It was left to fellow left-hander Shivnarine Chanderpaul to hold the lodge together with a gritty 54 despite the handicap of an injured groin.
Chanderpaul was forced to rely on a runner for most of his innings after he was injured, while running back to his crease to avoid being run out.
Pakistan, who arrive in Australia later this month, are the other team competing in the World Series tournament.

CRICKET - LARA SUFFERS MORE MISERY ON AUSTRALIAN TOUR.

West Indies batsman Brian Lara suffered another blow on his Australian tour after already being disciplined for misconduct when he was dismissed narrowly in the first limited-overs match against Australia on Friday.
Lara, who earned a severe reprimand from his own tour management after an angry outburst against Australian wicketkeeper Ian Healy, scored five to extend a run of poor form with the bat.
The West Indies vice-captain fought for time during his 36-minute stay at the crease before chipping a ball from medium pacer Tom Moody straight to Shane Warne at mid-wicket.
West Indies were 53 for two in 15 overs when rain stopped play at the Melbourne cricket ground after captain Courtney Walsh won the toss and elected to bat.
Lara's outburst three days ago clearly turned part of the Australian public against him.
As he walked to the wicket, he was greeted by loud jeers from sections of the crowd.
On several occasions during his shift, the crowd joined in a series of obscene chants against him.

Tour manager Clive Lloyd on Wednesday apologised for Lara's behaviour as he confronted Australian coach Geoff Marsh in the opposition dressing room to protest his dismissal in the second test on Tuesday.
Lloyd did not say what form the discipline would take.
Lara, who holds the record for the highest score in Test and first-class cricket, was unhappy with Healy's role in the incident and questioned whether the ball had taken to the Australian keeper.
Australia won the match at the Sydney Cricket Ground by 124 runs to take a two-nil lead in the five-Test series after Lara failed in both innings.
Lara has yet to score a century since the West Indies arrived in Australia five weeks ago.
Both the West Indies and Australian team administrations played down the incident, stressing that relations between the two sides were not adversely affected.
Pakistan, who arrive next week, are the third team in the triangular World Series tournament.
